text: How does that script know when a version is released before it's copied to -latest?

elements.text: How does that script know when a version is released before it's copied to -latest?

text:
What's -latest?

It checks the github API for tags on julialang/julia and then tries to download all potential file names for all tags

elements.text:
What's -latest?

It checks the github API for tags on julialang/julia and then tries to download all potential file names for all tags

text: So when a new 1.x is released, we have a file like julia-1.5.4-mac64.dmg which always points to 1.5.4 for Mac, but then we copy that as julia-1.5-latest-mac64.dmg which currently points to 1.5.4 and would later point to 1.5.5, 1.5.6, ...

elements.text: So when a new 1.x is released, we have a file like julia-1.5.4-mac64.dmg which always points to 1.5.4 for Mac, but then we copy that as julia-1.5-latest-mac64.dmg which currently points to 1.5.4 and would later point to 1.5.5, 1.5.6, ...

text: The -latest aliases are what other CI systems use when you request a particular 1.x

elements.text: The -latest aliases are what other CI systems use when you request a particular 1.x

text:
Ah okay. versions.json only has the fixed files like julia-1.5.4-mac64.dmg. I'd have to search for the exact issue, but the file was intended to be largely immutable/append-only.

The GHA script tries to find the highest version in versions.json that matches `1.x` and then uses that. It doesn't use -latest

elements.text:

The GHA script tries to find the highest version in versions.json that matches
and then uses that. It doesn't use -latest

text: So I think to keep versions.json from picking up the macOS binaries before they're notarized, I'll just need to make sure they can't be read (i.e. not set the ACL to public-read) before they're notarized.

elements.text: So I think to keep versions.json from picking up the macOS binaries before they're notarized, I'll just need to make sure they can't be read (i.e. not set the ACL to public-read) before they're notarized.

text:
versions.json is rebuilt every 24 hours at the moment, so the error would eventually fix itself. But I can understand that it's a bit frustrating to see failures shortly after a release has been announced until it's been fixed.

There are various changes to the script that could improve this, but I'm not gonna bother before the script has been moved since it's a larger rewrite.

For example if it wouldn't download _all_ versions in the history of Julia, it could try a rebuild once an hour in the first week after a release, and only upload if there have been changes.

text:
`versions.json` doesn't have an entry for that Windows binary yet. The installation script is technically meant to throw an error in that case rather than failing silently, but apparently that error is not being displayed.

The script must've built versions.json at a really inconvenient time? :neutral_face:

`versions.json` has been rebuilt, so whenever the cache expires (?) and <https://julialang-s3.julialang.org/bin/versions.json> has the latest version, it should work

text:
No idea. It uses `aws s3 cp versions.json <s3://julialang2/bin/versions.json> --acl public-read --no-progress` to upload the file. I don't know what happens to it afterwards.

I assume that there's some caching since <https://julialang-s3.julialang.org/bin/versions.json> doesn't update immediately after uploading a new file
